purpose: discuss and develop a set of evaluation criteria for exit from incubation to mature
text: <@U0KM61BCP|cbf> set the channel purpose: discuss and develop a set of evaluation criteria for exit from incubation to mature
diversity of contribution - a project must demonstrate that it has cultivated a broad set of contributors from multiple members (and/or non-members)
test coverage - a project must demonstrate some threshold of test coverage to be considered mature (we need to arrive at a reasonable threshold)
full reviews of security and cryptography
demonstration of meeting minimal scaling requirements
re: test coverage, some portions need greater priority than others, such as cryptographic and consensus code. Having some guides to where code risks are is important before exit-criteria can be met.
<@U0UFDAS91>: scale along which dimensions? transactions per second, amount of decentralization, number of transaction initiators, diversity of applications, ...

<@U0KPYF3PF>: all that are appropriate for the use cases assigned to be required. For instance your PoET may be too slow for some use cases, but allows larger federations and easier entry and exit of members that PBFT does not for other use cases.

that sounds like what i meant by having more than one "optimization" point. another potential scale definition (which only SCP among consensus mechanisms I'm aware of will meet) is that "more resources increase capacity"
both standard consensus algorithm families are constrained in the dimension
comply with a set of core-requirements derived from the results of the req.-stream
<@U0MJBP0KZ>: think we need to be careful not to turn this into waterfall
think that an MVP needs to be defined
<!channel>: just popping this back on the stack… would be good to make some progress on this discussion
with regards to MVP, each incubating project should define its MVP either before, or shortly after acceptance into incubation. If before, it should be included in the proposal
if after, should be reviewed by TSC
exiting incubation requires that the MVP criteria be demonstrably met

Another questions for <#C10NZ55GU> is how it evaluates output from requirements and architecture WGs regarding a particular incubation. As MVPs will likely be subset of requirements and/or architecture.

<@U0P2GSA8Z> <@U0KM61BCP>:  I tried to be explicit in the table I added to the doc last week, if it is a help. For example, "TSC attests to fully functional code base, documentation and suitability for usage as:
Defined in formal documentation
Characterized across following dimensions:
functional 
technical

As verified by past and ongoing reviews

I'm wondering whether the restriction on what can be changed in a mature project isn't going too far
in the exit criteria draft, jeremy added a table
oh I’ll have to go look
exit from incubation not a function of done-ness
My thought is not about doneness, but about what's blessed by the TSC using which criteria and when.

E.g., if the TSC designates a project as mature, does that mean it follows a consistent change control process? E.g., that any designated release has been reviewed via the defined gerritt reviewers? I.e., it's followed a change control process and release process?
E.g., how far can the design and implementation change or vary from what the TSC ok'ed before it has to go back to the proposal process?
Or does the TSC give up all control and responsibility once a project is promoted to mature because the project itself is capable of handling it on its own?

The reason to be explicit is that the discussions have made clear that some folks may misinterpret "mature" as an attestation. Following a release process is not just a DevOps thing. Often, people assume that a project following a release process has change controls, quality assurance and fit-for-purpose attestations being made.

I think this will be particularly important for Hyperledger, given the visibility and the potential for use with financial transactions. Therefore, I'd suggest making that distinction between project's maturity and what's being attested to and by whom front-and-center.
